text: Family Member: Okay. I heard Doctor: Well, BRCA2 also puts you at risk for melanoma, so. (pause) Patient: Well, I’ve got a lot of skin tags. So. It’s kind of, um, I don’t know if it’s because Nicotinamide somehow absorbs sunlight or how it would work? Patient: Well. I don’t know. Look at the alien show. Maybe you can figure it out. Doctor: Well. They’re all green, so they have a different problem. So. Family Member: They have different skin. Doctor: Yeah. Doctor: Right here? Family Member: Uh.

text: Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause) Doctor: Yeah um. Do you want to talk to him soon?

FAM Probably. I know you don’t necessarily start soon. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In terms of getting hormone therapy do you want to do it with us? He could do it too. Family Member: Oh, well, he only has to come in how often for that? Doctor: The most common way is once every three months. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And also… Family Member: And does he do it here in the office with you guys? Doctor: So typically it’s an injection. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s also a yearlong implant that you can do. I wouldn’t do it for your first injection, Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. Patient: Is that a study? Doctor: Yes.

text: Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There could either be zero or there could be some somewhere. It’s just not enough for it to be detectible. Family Member: Okay. text: Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level? Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So.

text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, can we do additional molecular testing that you and I talked about early on… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which you know we use a company called Caris. Patient: Right. Doctor: uh Molecular Intelligence. There are many. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So how are things going since the last time I saw you a couple months ago? Patient: I’m feelin’ fine. Well, let’s put it this way… Energy, lack of energy. That’s my number one complaint. Doctor: Okay. Is that getting any better, any worse or staying the same? Patient: I - It appears to be getting worse. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds.

text: Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: Because I know there are so many side effects. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target.

text: Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it?

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine.

So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
